claim: A 19-year-old female college student comes to the physician for a sudden loss of visual acuity of her right eye. She noticed that she was unable to read the time on the alarm clock when she woke up in the morning. When she closes her right eye, she is able to see sharply. When she closes her left eye, she has blurry double vision. She does not recall trauma to her eye but has been working long nights on her honors thesis. She has a history of occasional shoulder luxation. She is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall, and weighs 62 kg (136 lbs); her BMI is 19.1 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, slender and long fingers are noted. She has several flat, demarcated brownish nevi on her left cheek. Ocular examination shows upward temporal subluxation of her right lens. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient? : Joint hypermobility syndrome

supporting.text: The patient's history of occasional shoulder luxation and the physical finding of slender, long fingers are consistent with joint hypermobility, which is a hallmark feature of Joint Hypermobility Syndrome.

attacks.text: The patient's history of occasional shoulder luxation and the physical finding of slender, long fingers are consistent with joint hypermobility, which is a hallmark feature of Joint Hypermobility Syndrome.

The patient's ocular findings, such as upward temporal subluxation of the right lens, are more indicative of a connective tissue disorder like Marfan syndrome rather than Joint Hypermobility Syndrome.
The patient's height and BMI, along with the physical findings, suggest Marfan syndrome, which is more likely to present with lens subluxation and other systemic features.
Joint Hypermobility Syndrome can present with ocular manifestations, including lens subluxation, though less commonly than in Marfan syndrome.
The presence of flat, demarcated brownish nevi is not typically associated with Marfan syndrome, which may suggest another diagnosis or a coincidental finding.
While lens subluxation can occur in Joint Hypermobility Syndrome, it is rare and usually less severe than in Marfan syndrome, making the latter more likely in this case.

supporting.text: The upward temporal subluxation of the right lens is a classic ocular manifestation of connective tissue disorders, including Joint Hypermobility Syndrome, due to weakened zonular fibers.

attacks.text: The upward temporal subluxation of the right lens is a classic ocular manifestation of connective tissue disorders, including Joint Hypermobility Syndrome, due to weakened zonular fibers.
The patient's slender and long fingers, along with flat brownish nevi, are more indicative of Marfan syndrome than Joint Hypermobility Syndrome, as these are hallmark features of Marfan syndrome.

The patient's history of occasional shoulder luxation and lens subluxation could also be caused by Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, another connective tissue disorder, making Joint Hypermobility Syndrome less specific.
Marfan syndrome typically presents with aortic root dilation, which has not been mentioned in the patient's history or examination, reducing its likelihood compared to Joint Hypermobility Syndrome.
Ehlers-Danlos syndrome often includes hyperextensible skin and easy bruising, neither of which are reported in this patient, making Joint Hypermobility Syndrome a more plausible diagnosis.
The absence of aortic root dilation does not rule out Marfan syndrome, as it can present later in life or be absent in some variants, keeping Marfan syndrome a viable differential.

The hyperextensible skin and easy bruising are more common in the vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, and their absence does not exclude other types that could still explain the patient's symptoms.

supporting.text: The patient's tall stature and low BMI are often associated with connective tissue disorders, further supporting the diagnosis of Joint Hypermobility Syndrome.

attacks.text: The patient's tall stature and low BMI are often associated with connective tissue disorders, further supporting the diagnosis of Joint Hypermobility Syndrome.
Tall stature and low BMI are not specific to Joint Hypermobility Syndrome and can be seen in many other conditions, including Marfan syndrome.
The patient's ocular findings (lens subluxation) are more characteristic of Marfan syndrome than Joint Hypermobility Syndrome.
Marfan syndrome typically presents with aortic root dilation, which is not mentioned in this patient's history or examination.
Joint Hypermobility Syndrome can also present with lens subluxation, though it is less common than in Marfan syndrome.
The absence of aortic root dilation does not rule out Marfan syndrome, as it may develop later in life or may not have been assessed in this visit.
Lens subluxation in Joint Hypermobility Syndrome is rare and usually less severe than in Marfan syndrome, making Marfan syndrome more likely in this case.

supporting.text: The absence of trauma and the presence of systemic features (e.g., joint hypermobility, lens subluxation) make localized eye conditions (e.g., trauma-induced lens dislocation) less likely, pointing toward a systemic diagnosis like Joint Hypermobility Syndrome.

attacks.text: The absence of trauma and the presence of systemic features (e.g., joint hypermobility, lens subluxation) make localized eye conditions (e.g., trauma-induced lens dislocation) less likely, pointing toward a systemic diagnosis like Joint Hypermobility Syndrome.
Lens subluxation can also occur in Marfan syndrome, which shares features like joint hypermobility and slender build, making it a plausible alternative diagnosis.
The patient's nevi and lens subluxation could suggest Homocystinuria, another systemic condition that mimics some features of Joint Hypermobility Syndrome.
Marfan syndrome is less likely without aortic root dilation or other cardiovascular findings, which are hallmark features of the disease.
Homocystinuria typically presents with intellectual disability and thromboembolic events, neither of which are reported in this patient, reducing its likelihood.
Early-stage Marfan syndrome may not yet exhibit aortic dilation, so its absence does not fully rule out the diagnosis.
Mild forms of Homocystinuria may lack classical features like intellectual disability, leaving lens subluxation as a key diagnostic clue.

supporting.text: The patient's flat, demarcated brownish nevi are not typically associated with Joint Hypermobility Syndrome and may suggest an alternative diagnosis, such as neurofibromatosis, which can also cause lens subluxation.

attacks.text: The patient's flat, demarcated brownish nevi are not typically associated with Joint Hypermobility Syndrome and may suggest an alternative diagnosis, such as neurofibromatosis, which can also cause lens subluxation.
The presence of brownish nevi is not pathognomonic for neurofibromatosis and could be incidental findings, thus not ruling out Joint Hypermobility Syndrome.
The patient's history of shoulder luxation and slender, long fingers are more consistent with Joint Hypermobility Syndrome than neurofibromatosis.
Neurofibromatosis often presents with other systemic features like café-au-lait spots or neurofibromas, which are absent here, making Joint Hypermobility Syndrome more likely.
Lens subluxation in neurofibromatosis is rare compared to its association with connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome or Joint Hypermobility Syndrome.
The absence of café-au-lait spots does not exclude neurofibromatosis, as clinical presentation can vary widely, and some patients may only exhibit subtle signs initially.
While lens subluxation is rare in neurofibromatosis, the patient's nevi and lack of classic Marfanoid features still make it a plausible differential diagnosis.

supporting.text: The sudden loss of visual acuity and lens subluxation could be due to Marfan syndrome, another connective tissue disorder, which shares features with Joint Hypermobility Syndrome but has distinct cardiovascular implications.

attacks.text: The sudden loss of visual acuity and lens subluxation could be due to Marfan syndrome, another connective tissue disorder, which shares features with Joint Hypermobility Syndrome but has distinct cardiovascular implications.
The patient's slender build, long fingers, and lens subluxation are classic features of Marfan syndrome, making it a more likely diagnosis than Joint Hypermobility Syndrome.
The absence of reported cardiovascular symptoms does not rule out Marfan syndrome, as cardiovascular complications may not be immediately apparent in young patients.
Joint Hypermobility Syndrome is more common and less severe than Marfan syndrome, and the patient's history of shoulder luxation could be more indicative of Joint Hypermobility Syndrome.
The presence of flat, demarcated brownish nevi is not a typical feature of Marfan syndrome, suggesting another diagnosis might be more appropriate.
Marfan syndrome is often underdiagnosed in its early stages, and the absence of cardiovascular symptoms does not exclude the possibility of the disease.
The nevi could be coincidental or related to another condition, and should not outweigh the more specific findings of lens subluxation and body habitus in diagnosing Marfan syndrome.

supporting.text: The patient's symptoms could also be explained by Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which has overlapping features with Joint Hypermobility Syndrome but includes more severe skin and vascular involvement.

attacks.text: The patient's symptoms could also be explained by Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which has overlapping features with Joint Hypermobility Syndrome but includes more severe skin and vascular involvement.
The patient lacks severe skin or vascular symptoms typical of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, making Joint Hypermobility Syndrome more likely.
The presence of lens subluxation is a hallmark feature of Marfan syndrome, not Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which suggests an alternative diagnosis.
While the patient lacks severe skin or vascular symptoms, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome can present variably, and mild forms may not exhibit these features.
Lens subluxation can occur in both Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, so it does not rule out Ehlers-Danlos syndrome entirely.
The absence of aortic root dilation or other cardiovascular abnormalities makes Marfan syndrome less likely than Ehlers-Danlos syndrome in this patient.
The patient's slender build and long fingers are more consistent with Marfan syndrome than Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, despite the lens subluxation being a shared feature.
